reviews.review_title: A flop that came of age
reviews.content: Ok, so at the time of cinematic release the world declared it to be pants. Who could blame them after the original? Had I been old enough to go to see it at the time I would have agreed, being a 'Grease' obsessive myself. Watching it now, however, I wonder what it was that rattled everyone's cage so much. Not-just-a-pretty-face Caulfield actually put in a decent performance, Pfeiffer's Zinone was remarkably accurate for such a novice actress and Luft could certainly bust a note or two. 'Score Tonight' is undeniably catchy, 'Reproduction' could carry the whole film itself, and the lovely Frechette's 'Do It For Our Country' was inspired. Since time has gone by the film has become somewhat of a classic. Since probably everyone you know probably knows at least one of the tunes, they can't really have been so terrible, can they? Basically, all I'm trying to say is, don't look too deep, don't compare, just laugh, sing along and I dare you to not be crooning 'Cool Rider' in the shower tomorrow. Yes, at times the film does fit into the so-bad-it's-good cliche. But I rather feel the film-makers are in on the joke.

reviews.review_title: People's enjoyment of it will depend on what they take away from it no matter the varying reasons.
reviews.content: Set in 1961 Grease 2 picks up four years after where the first movie left off. It sees newcomer Michael Carrington, who just recently arrived at Rydell as an exchange student from England falling for the beautiful Stephanie Zinone. However she shows no interest in him romantically as being the leader of the Pink Ladies, rules dictate that she and her friends can only date gang members of the T-Birds. Undeterred Michael formulates a plan to win her affection much to the ire of T-Bird leader Johnny Nogrelli.Given the phenomenal commercial success and its cult status it would have seemed inevitable that a sequel would be on the cards. Allan Carr, who was co-producer had made a deal with Paramount Pictures to be paid $5 million to produce a sequel within three years of its predecessors' theatrical release, and he delivered on that promise. Bringing in professional dance choreographer Patricia Birch, who had worked on the original's choreography to direct, she undoubtedly had a lot to live up to given its reputation. An almost entirely new team of actors was cast, and the overall result although not completely utterly awful, still to this day leaves something to be desired.To it's credit the majority of the songs are very catchy and dare I go so far as say, memorable with some energetic, well-choreographed dance routines. It's certainly not boring and you get the distinct feeling that there is at least some attempt to do right by the fans by doing justice to what came before. However, the major flaw is with its uneven script which relies a bit too much on toilet humour, some of which at the time wouldn't have been enough to justify its PG certificate. That said there are some genuinely funny and inspired moments where I found myself laughing a bit more than I should have been. There are attempts as well to be larger than life, too larger than life in fact as are most of its characters. The only members of the cast who seem at all restrained are its two leads although Maxwell Caulfield with his smoldering good looks which would no doubt have sent female cinemagoers' pulses racing is a poor substitute for John Travolta. He just lacks Travolta's charisma, and there's definitely something lacking in terms of chemistry between him and co-star Michelle Pfieffer, who incidentally comes off significantly better. Actually, hers is one of the best performances of the movie with her portrayal of the gutsy Stephanie. Her high-octane performance of the super-fueled Cool Rider puts the Power in Girl Power long before the term had been invented, and you can see the early signs that she had what it took to be a star.Besides the lack of spark between them the plot involving Michael adopting a mysterious, masked biker alter ego in an attempt to woo the girl that he adores undermines the validity of any feelings that Stephanie has for him. Her "love" for him comes across as mere infatuation which is purely superficial. This is the girl who after all sang that she wants a Cool Rider with a motorcycle, "No ordinary boy is gonna do. I want a rider that's cool". It doesn't make her look good and she comes off as an immature young woman with a shallow schoolgirl crush. The flipping of each side of the high school cliques that two lead protagonists come from, an obvious attempt to put a new spin on what made the first movie successful does little to alter the fact that this is still a retread over the same story, with an unconvincing main plot development thrown in.The overall quality of the acting from the new kids is decidedly patchy, with Adrian Zmed amusingly cocky without becoming overly obnoxious. Any reservations about them there may be, he manages to be likable although indications may point to the contrary early on. Lorna Luft as the blonde bimbo Paulette pouts and overdoes the breathy voice in an attempt to channel Marilyn Monroe, but it merely grates although she does come into her own more in a later scene when she dials it down. And while it is great to see the returning cast members make an appearance, with the glorious Eve Arden reprising her role as, school principal, Miss McGee, it's pretty unforgivable to see Didi Conn as Frenchy largely wasted with little screen time she is given and with a contrived explanation as to her presence.In the end Grease 2 is something of an admirable failure that misses more than it hits but when it does hit it does with considerable impact. The kitsch cheesiness of it however has meant that it has gained something of a minor cult status, perhaps by those who find it so bad to be good (although it's not even bad enough by my personal estimations to gain such dubious an honour) or those with lower expectations than others. It has made its mark and whether you choose to embrace it or not, if you go for the former then I suppose it doesn't matter why it is if you can find something to enjoy.

"Grease 2" isn't a sequel to "Grease", but rather a less-than-stellar rehash set two years later with different characters.Michael Carrington (played by Maxwell Caulfield, who has struggled in his big screen career since this bullet) is new to Rydell, transferring from England (one of the only ways this movie is related to the first film is that he's Sandy's cousin). Within the first week of school, he's fallen for the head of the Pink Ladies, Stephanie Zinone (played by then newbie, Michelle Pfeiffer. Wow, I guess when they say you have to start from the bottom and work your way up, they really meant it, eh Michelle?) But Stephanie isn't looking for a nerd like Michael, she's looking for a cool rider! One that rides motorcycles in skin tight leather! So basically, the movie is a simple gender-switch of the first movie, following Michael's quest to change his image and win over Stephanie.One thing that is disappointing is that this movie had so much potential, but never lived up to it. They could have given us a bit of history about the T-Birds and Pink Ladies. But do we get it? No. They could have given us some exciting new types of music that could have made this installment just as good as the last. Did we get it? No. There are plot holes throughout, and lacks a lot of originality. Did we need another mushy love story? No, we already saw that in the first movie. The original stars didn't come back, so I think the last thing they should have done was repeat the story! They could have shown us how one becomes a member of the T-Birds or The Pink Ladies, other than looking hot. But did they tell us? No. Their was just suddenly a new batch of Pink Ladies and T-Birds, and I suppose there's a new batch every year, but leave it to "Grease 2" to never explain it to us.How are the new T-Birds and Pink Ladies selected? We'll never know now. This movie had so much potential, could have had new clothes, new music, new everything, but no. We basically get a gender switch of the original "Grease", with the same music, same clothes, just different people, proving the producers and director were lazy and just looking for money, like they threw this whole movie together in 6 months.The acting is nothing great. The only people who shine in this movie are Adrian Zmed as the corky Johnny Nogorelli, Michelle Pfeiffer (who would obviously go on to do bigger and better things), and the famous Lorna Luft (Judy Garland's daughter), who plays Johnny's desperate stalker. However, leading man Maxwell Caulfield looks like he's trying to hard and comes off as annoying, unlike Olivia Newton-John was in the original version. Even Adrian Zmed looks like he's trying to copy John Travolta, but fails. As for the other T-Birds and Pink Ladies, they weren't memorable at all.The characters themselves aren't that great. They aren't very likable, and act like they just got out of juvee. The script is definitely lacking, and much of the dialogue is pretty bad and annoying.The songs? Well, some of them are somewhat catchy, but for the most part, fail at keeping your attention. The singing is also extremely;y second rate as well. Maxwell Caulfield sounds like he's struggling to hold a tune (wow how the hell did this kid get cast in this movie?!?) and the more professional singers such as Lorna Luft maybe get one solo throughout the movie, which brings me to another huge mistake in the movie. Who the hell decided to cast a bunch of unknowns in a big movie musical?!? And in a sequel to the highest grossing movies musical of all time?!? Bad move, very bad move.The film opens with "Back To School Again", which is the best song on the soundtrack, mainly because none of the kids from the cast sing it. 15 minutes later, the gang bursts into a song about bowling called "Score Tonight", which I guess was meant to be a big dance number/group ensemble, like "Summer Nights" was in the original. The song is catchy, except how does bowling relate to the movie's plot? It was a pointless song, and it was obviously just thrown into the movie for the sake of it. Were the filmmakers that lazy? Then Michelle Pfeiffer bursts into a song called "Cool Rider". It's a good song, actually, except the dance she does is pretty goofy and distracting in a bad way. Also, the song doesn't sound very 60s, it screams 1982. Time warp, anyone? Then there's a song about "Reproduction". See what I said about "Score Tonight". Same thing applies here. And then there's a string of unmemorable songs in the movie as well.The movie lacks the magic the original movie had. It has no energy, and in the original the songs just exploded into your face, but in "Grease 2", it doesn't lift off the screen. The characters aren't likable for the most part and it doesn't have any energy, motivation, and most of all, it doesn't have any effort. This movie claims to take place in 1961 when most of it screams 1982. Everyone who made this movie seemed to just be looking for money and not even caring about the movie itself. Hence, the laziness. I'm glad this movie flopped at the box office, because it proves you can't make it in Hollywood if you're lazy. So why did I give it a 4 out of 10? Because, even amidst all of it's terribleness, there are a few (and when I mean "few", I mean "few") good songs, a few exceptional performances (Adrian, Lorna, and Michelle), and there's a little bit of chemistry between the two leads, Michelle and Michael, most noticeable in the diner scene. Skip this turkey, only for the die-hard "Grease" fans.

reviews.review_title: Well, at least there won't be a "Grease 3"
reviews.content: This movie isn't as bad as its reputation would suggest, but it is a totally unnecessary follow-up to the 1978 classic. It is sporadically entertaining, and it does have a few things going for it. The early screen appearance of Michelle Pfeiffer is interesting to watch, and I enjoyed her performance. Almost all of the actors are quite likable, actually, giving energetic and engaging performances. And the film boasts the welcome return of Dody Goodman, Eve Arden and Sid Caesar from the original "Grease."So what is the problem? First of all, the storyline is rather far-fetched. "Nerdy" English student (Sandy's cousin...yeah, right) falls for Pink Lady who wants nothing to do with him, so he learns to ride a motorcycle amazingly quickly and becomes this mysterious "cool rider" while the other characters don't even recognize him. I guess it's a Clark Kent/Superman kind of thing. Secondly, the songs are nothing to write home about...actually, the songs from the ORIGINAL film weren't that terrific either, but at least they became hits. Most of the cast members aren't particularly strong singers, but their dedication and energy almost makes up for it. The direction is sluggish, and the editing is poor. But the biggest failure here is the blandly-handsome Maxwell Caulfield in the lead role of straight-A/cool rider Michael Carrington. His performance is dull, his diction is poor, his screen presence is non-existent and his singing is pathetic. And he hasn't done anything noteworthy since.But honestly, the film isn't all bad. Stupid and forgettable, but not necessarily painful. But it is far from a must-see. Watch only if you are too tired to get up and change the channel and the remote isn't working.

I admit "Grease 2" starts out promising with the big dance number opening and the song "Back To School" by the Four Tops, but it's all downhill from there.  This film has become famous not only for its badness, but as one of the first films of Michelle Pfeiffer.  Other actors who have risen above this are Chistopher MacDonald (who played the T-Bird Goose), who starred in "SLC PUNK," "Thelma and Louise," and many other movies, and Pamela Segall, who played Dolores Rebchuck (Paulette's little sister who's always trying to hang out with the Pink Ladies) has done a lot of voiceover work (though she does occasionally make an acting appearance, such as in HBO's "Breast Men") and most of you probably know her as the voice of Bobby Hill in "King of the Hill". As for the songs being hideous, well, you have Louis St. Louis to thank for that, the man who did the original music for "Grease" (or at least a good part of it).  Notice the similarities between the melodies of "Girl for All Seasons" and "Beauty School Dropout" from the original "Grease." Musical lightning doesn't always strike twice, just ask Richard O'Brien, who did the music for "Rocky Horror Picture Show" and then also did the music for the awful sequel "Shock Treatment." However, I have to admit that "Grease 2" has one of the funniest lines I've ever heard onscreen: "I'm going to die and I'm wearing my mother's underwear!" reviews.review_title: Strong contender for worst sequel ever made
reviews.content: Grease was a great musical for three reasons. One, the cast could sing. Two, the songs were memorable. Three, the choreography was great (Born to Hand Jive, anyone?). Unfortunately, when making Grease 2 no-one seemed to think that these elements were particularly important.I never normally feel compelled to write comments on here about the films I have seen. However, just having sat through the monstrosity that is Grease 2 I simply had to act. From start to pathetic end, this musical is terrible. It's meant to be set in 1961, but a lot of the songs ("Cool Rider" especially) seem to have been influenced by 1970s guitar rock like Meatloaf, so they seem completely out of place. The singing is appalling - why did no-one think to cast actors who could sing? Or just dub them with singers who could?! The music is even badly edited - take for instance "Charade", where you can't make out a single lyric thanks to terrible diction combined with a vocal laid far too quiet on the mix. Most of the songs are multi-tracked for some strange reason too - so those weak voices come at you 4-strong at a time, making the overall sound very 80s. Some songs seem horribly out of place...why sing a really chirpy song when Michael (aka the Cool Rider) is presumed dead, then finish with a slow ballad for the finale when it's discovered he's alive and his identity is revealed?! Rama- dama-ding-a-long it ain't.As for the choreography - look at the song set in the bowling alley if you don't get what I'm talking about. It's supposed to be a big set number, so why is the dancing so unimaginative? Most of it just involves twirling around (a lot!) and throwing the suddenly miraculously light bowling balls!As for the cast, they all look incredibly old - the leader of the rival gang (also in the first film - forgive me not knowing the character's name but he's the one who dates Cha Cha) could easily pass for 45. Pfeiffer, here in an early role, is grumpy and petulant for most of the film, leaving you to wonder why Michael goes to all the bother of wooing her in the first place. Her singing is dreadful, her face inexpressive, and she gets the frumpiest outfits of all the Pink Ladies.Finally, numerous plot points are unexplained: Why are the T-birds, so cool in the first film, now bothered about a stupid talent contest? Why do they all now ride bikes instead of cool cars? What happens to Frenchie - she just disappears halfway through the film?! Why is Sandy's cousin Michael English, when she is Australian? What happened to the end of year funfair in the first Grease film...we now get a cheap Lu-ow (sic) instead...run out of budget did we?I suppose if you want to have a quick look, it has a certain"It's so bad it's good" quality, which is why I suppose some people have voted this film a ten, but in reality it's painful to sit through it all. Fans of Grease would be better off imagining and writing a Grease 2 of their own - frankly a trained monkey couldn't do worse.

reviews.review_title: A grossly underrated and underappreciated film
reviews.content: Though I prefer to stay away from sequels, because as a rule they are almost always not even half the film of the original. But this is one of those rare exceptions, where it's twice the film, and here most tend knock it more than praise it. What's a matter, not enough trashy gimmicks like sex and gore to go around? Geez folks lighten up! This takes me back to the "Welcome Back Cotter" days. Perhaps I made the mistake of seeing this one first in theaters as a small boy, before I saw the original?... I don't know... Anyhow, the soundtrack's far superior to the original, w/ "Coooolll Rider" and the "Mistress for all Seasons" tune. IMHO motorbikes are far cooler than cars. High testosterone powered bikers are far cooler than a bunch of pansy mamma's boys as the first film focused on. Pfeifer's best work is Ms. Zanone and even one-hit-wonder actor Adrian Zmed is classic as her jerky boyfriend... So I ask you again, what's so terribly bad about this film?

Simply knowing that I willnever again reach the level of ecstacy I achieved on my maidenVoyage with Grease Too  has spun my life down a bottomlessspiral of despair.  This kind of magic doesn't come around often, and I think it has alot to do with an experimental program of the time which hadstudios hiring 'special' people to write incredibly bad jokes inpathetic movies in exchange for moderate tax breaks.  The musicis more or less on par with the script though I don't think there wasany equivalent program for songwriters - perhaps it was acoincidence that they ended up with 'special'  composers ormaybe the writer brought someone in from his day camp.

He is gold from start tofinish, as usual, and perhaps the only flaw of the movie is that hemakes the other performers look like the amateurs they are. 
Grease is no longer the word.  The word is Grease 2.

reviews.review_title: My favorite movie of all time!
reviews.content: Ok first off I just gotta say this movie changed my life in 1982. I was 12 years old and this movie did so much for me I can't begin to tell you all. reviews.review_title: Not really that bad a sequel

At times the film does not look like it is set in the early 1960's, and some of the musical numbers seem to be more in keeping with the 1980's. However, the Hawaiian luau sequence was perfect for the silly innocence of the times before President Kennedy was assassinated.I thought Michelle Pfeiffer and Maxwell Caulfield were both attractive leads, even if their singing and dancing abilities are limited. As I never was too keen on the original Grease, that is why I was not very disappointed with Grease 2, as many apparently are.

'Watch it as a stand alone movie' reviewers say, but yet they call it Grease 2. Everything about this movie is a D Grade.The acting... the soundtrack...crap.It's really bad.

And like many off you i made the mistake of trying to judge it against Grease and you just can't do that.When i watched it for the second time i was Amazed by just how musically good this movie is. Absolute hot garbage of a movie. No one should have to be subjugated to the complete torture that is Grease 2. The songs are uninteresting, the characters are almost carbon copies of the originals but with zero percent of the charm and the dialogue seems to be written by someone who had only heard of the original Grease from someone who saw it three years ago. OK, at the risk of being lynched, I'll say it.  The original Grease was not that great.  Definitely overrated.  But, I LOVED Grease 2. reviews.review_title: A much funnier version of the original.
reviews.content: Grease 2 is much more fun movie than Grease.  The songs are catchier and the characters, especially Johnny, are much less serious.  I'd recommend it.

reviews.review_title: Better than it's given credit for
reviews.content: We saw this movie before the original "Grease," and have always preferred "2." We identify more with the characters, the humor, the whole "superhero shtick," and fell in love with Michelle Pfeiffer long before we saw her in anything else! Lorna Luft as Paulette was a hoot, and we enjoyed the rest of the cast, including the "returning faculty" from "Grease," some of whom we remember from their old TV shows. The bomb shelter scene was especially meaningful to "baby boomer's" who grew up in the 50's and 60's. Our favorite song is "Cool Rider," and the ending chorus to "A Girl for All Seasons" was especially poignant. This was our generation, we are class of '63 in NJ and '64 in Georgia.

if you really liked the first one then you will most likely find yourself comparing grease 2 to the first one and really wont like it at all.it's not very funny.if you have a craving for some grease you should really skip this one and watch the original again instead!

reviews.review_title: Hard to Beat an Original But...
reviews.content: OK, so it is not the greatest lead up from a great original musical (and classic)like the first movie was; however, it is not entirely that bad in that it is what it is: a good, comfortable, Saturda or Sunda afternoon flick to watch in your PJs.Grease 2 had a lot of the original "feel good-ness" of the first, but the some of the musical numbers were reall not that good. As an example, the number where Stephanie sings with the "dead" nerd-turned-lover and newl heart throb, Michael Carrington, plaed by Max Caulfield. In addition, the actor taking over Travolta's part (sort of), Zmed, is not the handsome Travolta Danny Zucco is in the original.All in all, this movie had some pretty big shoes to fill, but it's not a bad little film to help you spend a laz weekend afternoon. So for that kind of entertainment value alone, I give it 5 out 10 stars.Grease is still the word.

This movie is not bad. It's got catchy songs and a much more positive message than Grease 1. Grease 1 was about a girl giving up her values to date a popular guy. Grease 2 is about an unpopular guy manipulating the shallow popular girl into liking him for who he is. At least he stays true to himself. And the music is fun.

I don't care what everyone says about this one. I think it's great. There are fansites, so i'm not the only one... I saw Grease 2 when i was 14 or so and i even saw it more often than Grease. Me, being a fan of Michelle Pfeiffer, was mad about it. I sang along all the songs (still do) and couldn't wait to finally own the soundtrack (which now, i do, after searching for years). I recognized Maxwell Caulfield from Dynasty, so i loved him at first sight too. I can honestly say it's one of my favorite films. Because of Michelle, Maxwell, the songs, the memory. I own it on DVD now and seeing it still gives me this surtain feeling. Some people get that at watching Grease, i get it when i'm enjoying Grease 2. Over and over again!

I can't for the life of me understand why people keep pulling this film down. It was exceptionally better than the first one, I think. Yeah, it is very cheesy but I just think its totally hilarious. The guy who played Louis DiMucci was totally gorge and I think the whole cast did quite a good job. The songs "Reproduction" and "Lets Do I For Our Country" never fail to have me screaming with laughter. Apart from Louis the best thing about this movie is Dolores Rebchuck (played by Pamela Seagal from King of The Hill). I think Michelle Pheiffer was really good in this and I totally disagree that it was a miracle her career didn't bomb after this. This movie gets a 9 1/2 out of 10 from me.

This is a movie I adored growing up. Watching it recently I remember why. Good looking girls, a catchy soundtrack, and a silly story made for an overly entertaining flick. It is nowhere near the first Grease in terms of quality, but I don't think the filmmakers intended to improve on the original as I don't think that would have been possible. Reding some of the scathing remarks about this movie makes me laugh. It is not bottom 100 bad by any means. My one huge complaint about this is that Maxwell Caulfield can't sing to save his life. Dubbing would have been a good thing. But look at the great characters. Johnny, Goose, Louis, Paulette, Sharon, Steph. Look at the great and fun songs. Cool Rider, Reproduction, Lets do it for our country. Good good stuff. 8 out of 10

reviews.review_title: This howls all the way to the pound!
reviews.content: How can a musical movie be cast with people who can't sing?  It just boggles the mind.  What could the casting director been thinking of?  Especially when you are casting a sequel that you have no doubt will be compared to the first movie.  Some of the actors had so many effects on their singing voices (I guess to make it tolerable to listen to), and it was still impossible to hide the fact that they just sang flat, had no viable range, and basically were really not bona fide singers.  Besides the fact that the songs were so inane it was pathetic.  I'm sure some of the actors like Michelle Pfeiffer and Maxwell Caulfield (mostly stage work these days, Broadway, et al) who still have a career in acting actually cringe when they know this movie will be on TV.  Lorna Luft's (the only real singer in the group) mom (Judy Garland) must have been rolling when this one hit the screen.  This one was a definite bow wow.

I just saw this again on late-nite TV. It is bad. It is bad, bad, BAD. There is no way to write the word "bad" powerfully enough to convey to you how bad. Michelle Pfeiffer would have to sneak up behind you in a darkened room, while you were just dropping off to sleep and scream BAD at the top of her castrated-chicken singing voice right in your ear for the word to convey any sort of sense of how campily dire this movie is....  First of all, this was directed (nominally) by one Patricia Birch. Why did nobody tell Ms. Birch that you can do this thing with the camera that's called "panning"? To her, this word seems to be nothing more than a description of what the critics did to her movie, and she seems completely unaware that it's also a form of camera movement. Hence she moves around scenes with cuts. All. The. Time. Which. Makes. Things. Kind. Of. Choppy. The result is that the movie looks like it was shot with a $12 polaroid instamatic camera and the pictures were then taped together. And Pat, sweetie, I LOVE that close-up shot of the back of Michelle Pfeiffer's head... Secondly; come on guys, you can tell us now. Was there actually a script? Or did you make it all up on the spot?Thirdly; Maxwell Caulfield. Sooooooo pretty. Sooooooo much prettier than Michelle Pfeiffer. Soooooooo unable to carry the movie. Or sing. Or, apparently, act. To be fair to Max, he does put in a decent performance in "The Boys Next Door", and the storyline here doesn't exactly help (It seems like he gets about 5 scenes in the whole movie, Michelle gets 7 and Adrian Zmed gets the rest to himself) OK, so the guy's singing is fairly horrible, but he's supposed to be the hero. And given that there was supposedly a massive search for the leads, shouldn't they have thought about that earlier? Pfeiffer is screechy enough to scare off Celine Dion. Zmed can sing a bit. (He does in "Bachelor Party" too). BTW, in real life, Max is married to Tabitha Lennox off "Passions". And Adrian Zmed has also been on "Passions". And Matt Lattanzi, who plays Brad here, was married to Olivia Newton John in real life. But I digress.  Fourthly, fifthly and sixthly: Oh God, the music is so awful! And yet I can't get "Score Tonight" out of my head. Continuity: If Michael's dead, who's playing the talent show music? And check out the 1980s cars driving past in the background when Max and Michelle are in the diner. T-Birds: Hello, these guys are a bunch of wussies. They should turn their bikes over to the girls and start using the pink Studebaker...
Seventhly: When climbing all over the dead motorbikes and singing about turning back time, wearing spangled jumpsuits, running in slow motion through dry-ice and cheap fades, didn't Max and Michelle get even the TINIEST inkling that this was not going to be a very good film at all?And in spite of all this, I watched the whole thing to the end of the credits. And past the Paramount logo. And I just spent five whole minutes writing this review (longer than was spent writing the script). It's that kind of film. Bad.

Jamie C. from Orlando here. I am still a huge fan of Grease 2. I used to emulate the dance moves with my friends. High school in a musical context is great. I like all the superlatives you can give the Grease 2 characters. I often times wish high school was more mature like the students there. reviews.review_title: It's really OK to like this movie!
reviews.content: Yes, yes, it is a terrible movie, but harmlessly so. It's funny, it's cheesy, it's upbeat, the songs are catchy, so don't be surprised if you catch yourself singing them! I also watched this movie over and over again in my teens with all my friends and we used to re-enact scenes and all. It's racier than Grease!

I have a theory that anyone who actually saw Grease 2 before they saw the original will agree that it is a better movie. I mean don't get me wrong, Grease the "OG" is a great film.... Classic. But I remember when my family first got HBO, I musta been 8 or so (seeing as it came out in '82 that seems about right) and I fell in love!!! I was a kid that actually "played" this movie. I based my whole coolness on that of the pink ladies. I wore satin jackets and even got one from my parents with my name on it. (Although it was purple) I didn't f-in care. The songs, Johnny Nogerelli, Goose, Louis Damuchi, Rhonda, Sharon, Paulette Rebchuck, The talent show, the Luau, the motorcycles, the leather, Michael Carrington and of course Stephanie Zanoni. F-in Ace!

reviews.review_title: Lighten up - this is supposed to be fun!
reviews.content: If you're looking for Grease, this is the wrong movie.  If you're looking for a fun way to spend a couple of hours, this is the right movie.  Yeah, Grease 2 is cheesy, but I don't trust anyone who doesn't like a little cheese.Michelle Pfeiffer provides a particularly entertaining performance as the lead, a female version of Danny from the original.The songs are catchy and the choreography is inspiring.  I challenge you to watch the entire movie without at least tapping your toes. I'm not embarrassed to admit that I tap my toes, wave my hands, and do a couple of spins every time I see it.So, all you armchair critics,  lighten up, turn the volume up, kick your heels up, and put the remote up. You won't find "Summer Lovin," but you will learn a little something about "Reproduction."

No one looked liked they were in high school except for Dolores. I took this movie exactly for what it was when it was when it came out - a practice film so everyone could get time in front of and behind the camera. Sure, the premise is a little thin. Sure, there's motorcycles instead of cars. But Michael was my first British boyfriend (the rest were real). I still quite enjoy the film separately and equally to the original Grease. We are not talking about deep topics.

reviews.review_title: almost as good as the original
reviews.content: i enjoyed this film!i know it's not as good as the original but it has the Grease feeling to it. the characters are a bit flat but the songs are catchy you find yourself singing them after you watch it. but if i was to pick between the original and this one i would pick the original as the story is better the songs are classic and every girl wanted to look as good as Olivia Newton John in those tight trousers!!!!!!! but this film is good it has the same kind of story but i have to admit it the original is the best!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Fantastic, my favourite film alongside Bambi!
reviews.content: I absolutely loved this film, it has everything, romance, action, adventure and most importantly-a happy ending!! Classic songs like 'Cool Rider' and the funky moves that go with them have kept me entertained for hours!! I highly recommend this film and give it my Johnny Boy 5 Stars!!!!

Yes, it does follow a similar storyline.., but then, so does every other movie that gets made. Instead of cars, they've gone on to motorcycles. I read they were going to do a series of movies, and then a t.v. show. Thank God they didn't! From 4 wheels to 2.. (cars to motorcycles) What would have been next? Unicycles? The music is enjoyable! reviews.review_title: Don't be afraid to admit you like it!
reviews.content: I've read so many reviews about this movie - Love It...Hate It - that it's hard to wrap my head around why such extremes.I guess there are those who loved the original Grease - I love both movies - and are loyal to the original.Much like those who prefer the earlier Star Wars films, but detest the prequels that were released 20 years after the originals and 20 years before the final chapters.I think a lot has to do the age when we all saw those movies. I was too young to remember the original Grease - yes, my older sister played the record constantly, but I saw the sequel as a 9-year old and bought the cassette that I played nonstop that summer of '82.You don't have to afraid to admit that you enjoy the sequel. I agree w/ other reviewers here that it's its own separate movie. They CAN stand alone.Yes, there are some carry-over cast from the original, but really just some dancers and faculty (well, I guess Eugene and Craterface return).Overall, yes, this story doesn't hold up well almost 40 years later, but how much have you and I changed during those years. I'm sure if you show this movie to the younger generation now and don't tell them that it's a "sequel" to the original, then they'll appreciate it for what it really is - good, (sort of) clean fun!

I enjoyed watching Miss McGee in the original but in this one she kind of looks older. This movie came out in the early 80's and I was born in 1985. So that is all I have to say. reviews.review_title: I'm sorry, but it really sucks!
reviews.content: I saw this movie on TV. But it was just so boring that I felt asleep! The story line was nothing, the music was nothing... Well, the guys were kind of cute but that's it. No catchy songs who makes you want to dance... I'm sorry, but it really sucks!

This movie is a bit much and the scenes and music are too goofy for me. The musical scenes and dialogue are quite bad The only reason I watched it was for the smoldering handsome Maxwell Caulfield. When he asks Michelle Pfeiffer's character "how about the day after tomorrow" in that sexy tone I about died.

I remember watching Grease 2 as a child and loving it. However, a few years ago, I watched it as an adult and I was disappointed. The acting could have used a lot of extra work, the actors didn't stand out like Travolta, Newton-John, Jeff Conaway, and Stockard Channing did. The plot of the movie put me to sleep. I mean, come on, Stephanie can't tell Michael from his geek personality and his greaser personality. How can she not know it's the same man?!? Almost all the actors in Grease 2 never made it beyond that movie. However, a year later, Michelle Pfeiffer would make up for Grease 2 by playing in Scarface with Al Pacino. Her role in Scarface put her on the map. I agree that she regrets being in Grease 2.

There areespecially three great sequences in Grease 2: 1) The opening number (Back to School), a great, catchy tune followed by some wonderful dancing, everything a musical should be. 2) "Score Tonight" which takes place in a bowling alley. Great song! And it's fun seeing everyone dancing with bowling bowls! 3) The biology class and "Reproduction", I dare say you won't stop humming it, hilarious and inventive. Sure, it has its weak spots, including some real cheesy scenes, and maxwell caulfield is no John Travolta (He hardly dances in the picture), he is supposed to look like a "Cool Rider" but looks instead like a Villain from the old "Batman" show with his "Cool Rider outfit". still, do not take this movie too seriously, Grease 2 sure don't deserve all the bad rep it got, and it sure deserves a much higher rating on IMDB. It's a fun little musical, with some great performances, inspired choreography and some really really great songs (And some not so great, but these are in the minority). Michell Pfeiffer is great in this picture and shouldn't be ashamed of it at all. To fully enjoy this, just try to forget that it's a sequel to the most succesful musical of all time (a heavy burden on any film), just call is "Brilliantine" or something instead of "Grease 2", because as a stand alone musical comedy, this flick delivers the goods.

When I first watched the movie, I was a little bit disappointed because I thought that the first movie was great and I expected a lot of the second one. But, after I watched the movie for the second time and the third time, I really started to like the movie. The songs in it are really catchy especially "cool rider" and " reproduction". Briefly, i just want to say that it's really scandalous that this movie is in the top 100 of the worst movies ever. I really can't understand it. I can immediately come up with 500 movies that are way worse than grease 2. I think the greatest problem is that most of the people want to compare this movie with the first one. I have no idea what is wrong with people bashing on this movie.Grease 2 is really really a great movie. I have watched it more than 10 times in my life and each time i'm having great fun watching it.I am very picky when it comes to movies. Most movies that i enjoy usually end up with an Oscar for best movie picture or something.Grease 2 is one of the few rare movies that i enjoy watching but didn't get any award.The way i see this is that Grease 2 is meant for a different type of audience.Back when i was in college, we (guys) had to impress girls in order to get them. We had to be cool, we had to be unreal (almost fake), we were creating an image to impress the girls. Of course, i don't do that anymore, (not as much. I'm married, got kids, and still got my motorcycle etc. But one thing that has changed since my college days is that i am more connected to reality now than i was in college.Grease 2 is about a nerds (maxwell) that wants THE Chix (pfeiffer ) but to do that he can't stay natural, he can't be himself so he has to impersonate an image. You see, this is exactly the daily reality for many teenagers. Observe how our teenagers behave today. No different than in Grease 2 (minus the music).I must admit, i was also a Geek guy trying to be cool, dreaming about some (impossible to get girl), when i was in college...and there was. Girls that (20 years later) i wish i had got even if my current wife is a very cute and sexy slim woman...Watching Grease 2 reminds me how i was in college. (like maxwell actually). To be more exact, i wished i was like maxwell. Because in Grease 2 he made it, he succeed getting pfeiffer. But in really it is much more complicated almost impossible for a Geek guy to get the most beautiful girl because the most beautiful girl usually can pick any guy she want.Being an educator in a high school, i can tell you that sex is probably to most spoken subject in our teenagers conversation and concern.To summarize: Grease 2 (from a guy point of view) is a movie for anyone who felt at one point in their college year in love with an (impossible to get girl). A guy who likes to dream and do crazy things just to impress someone, a good guy in nature.Grease 2 is a masterpiece (atleast) for some audience...I give it a 10/10 to re-balance that thrash reviews this movie has got but the real score should be around 8/10 objectively.

There are however some very catchy songs in Grease 2 but it is a change from the Grease many of us know and love and many people don't like change but i can definately assure you it does grow on you. This movie is great.  I am glad I didn't listen to some reviews and comments.  I love the original Grease movie but this is just as terrific in its own right.  I have watched this video more times than I would like to admit (the video is wearing out).  Maxwell Caulfield and the rest of the cast are terrific. reviews.review_title: Cinema with a flair of brilliance.
reviews.content: Patricia Birch's masterpiece is a stand-alone film, as possibly the greatest movie musical of all time.  As a sequel, it outlasts classics like the Godfather II or Porky's II: The Next Day.  It's timelessness and themes of the struggle of power versus love leave a lasting impression on even the least enchanted viewer.The characters of Michael and Stephanie are lovers from afar- he the mysterious answer to her dreams, she the temptress the likes of which can only be named Aphrodite.  Stephanie's struggle is outlined beautifully, as she fights to escape the clutches of the menacing Johnny, to find freedom in the wind on the back of Michael's motorcycle.  Her drop in class and status is simultaneous with her spiritual awakening found in Michael.To properly examine the acting acting, the cinematography, the set design, the directing, could take a lifetime.  Let us say simply this- there are three great films in cinema history.  They deal with power and love with unique, riveting dramatics- the first of those two: Citizen Kane, The Godfather.  The third is the word- again!

reviews.review_title: Some good content, but some pretty dead time, too! No spoilers!
reviews.content: I would never have made it through this had I not been too sick to do anything else. However, there are some good parts. Some of the singing and dancing numbers are fairly good and some of the characters work well together. The biggest problem, as I see it, is that neither of the two leads is much involved in any good numbers. I don't see a shred of chemistry between the leads, either. Maybe if someone else was in the role of Stefanie it might have improved things, but Michele Pfeiffer just isn't believable as a tough Italian girl (or a singer or dancer).I think Lorna Luft, although a bit old to play a high school student, did a very good job, although I wish there had been a number that showed off her voice. Another standout, in my opinion, was Leif Green, as Davey. I don't know why they would have him in a side car, rather than his own motorcycle. That was silly, but I think he did a great job with the role. If only the film had been stronger, it might have led to more of a career, for him. It was apparently expected to establish a career for Maxwell Caulfield, as well as Michele Pfeiffer. Although he was definitely very cute, I didn't really see much in the way of solid talent, there. While Michele Pfeiffer, although miscast in this film, in my opinion, did demonstrate some solid acting talent and later got the roles to prove it.

I truthfully don't like this movie. I don't see how it can even be considered a sequel to the original Grease. There is only had a few things in common and thats Frenchy (from what I remember she does not even have that much of a part) the T-birds and Pink ladies and the same high school. It's not that the movie was bad it is just that it is not relative to the original. A better sequel would be having Sandy and Danny get married and them going to a high school reunion. But that is not what happened it had something to with Frenchies cousin from England and how hes in love with a girl who is out of his league. Over all I think this movie could have at least related to the original, although it is true that no sequel can follow a truly great film it could have been a little bit better.

reviews.review_title: Its still the word, but I don't wanna say it anymore
reviews.content: This crap sandwich lacked some important elements.  A leading man that could sing. Common. Travolta was cool because there wasn't anything he couldn't do. He sang, danced, and acted.  The story wasn't so bad it was just that the songs and the singers were horrible...and this was a musical.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the original, but not half bad
reviews.content: Well, I must say that this sequel in does not live up to the original, but it does have its good points.  Among those are the opening song "Back to School" and its accompanying dance sequence, the acting jobs of Michelle Pfeiffer and Maxwell Caulfield, and the reappearance of characters from the original like Frenchy.  And, I never knew that Pfeiffer could sing, but she really shows off her singing talents here.  But, then there are the bad points like the song when Stephanie (Pfeiffer) thinks that the Cool Rider (Caulfield) has died and the reappearance of villian from the original.  I mean, why is he still terrorizing the T-Byrds?  But, all in all, it is a pretty good movie with upbeat music and dance numbers, good performances, and a good storyline.  Rent it for yourself, and make your own judgments.

Anyone who thinks that piece of trash original is better than this masterpiece probably spent their childhood eating lead paint chips or suffers from fetal alcohol syndrome. Seriously why did this not sweep the Oscar's that year? It inspired a generation to be cool riders. Also, it stars THE Maxwell Caulfield. Pity his costar Michelle something didn't do much after this. I had high hopes for her.This movie also led to a groundbreaking TV series that was also ahead of its time and deserves a second look. If you have any free time at all you really need to watch this, both the theatrical release and the directors cut if you can find a copy of it.

Is it just me or does the cast of Grease 2 simply lacks some of the charm and life of the original cast? I understand that many fans don't like Grease 2 to be compared to the original Grease, but even as a standalone movie it's cheesy. The gang members of the T-Birds are about as cool as Eugene the local nerd and most of the Pink Ladies seem to have room for rent upstairs (and downstairs, if you listen to some of the songs). Michael (Maxwell Caulfield) doesn't seem to realize the Catch-Of-The-Day Stephanie (Michelle Pfeiffer) is possibly less of a catch than little Dolores (Pamela Adlon) who isn't even old enough to be dating any of the T-Birds. Oh well, at least she's genuinely interested in being Michael's friend. Not enough screen time for her or for Frenchy (Didi Conn) who is seen messing with mysterious chemicals in several of her cameos. They're cameos, not an actual role: not enough screen time for an actual role.The songs are less than memorable but some of them make you laugh if only because of their obvious sexual innuendos. I'm not an expert on singing but at least the characters in Grease 2 beat out currently-popular Hannah Montana and most of the Jonas Brothers' songs.One last thing: Why can't the nerds in my school be studs?

reviews.review_title: Doesn't have to be compared to the original...
reviews.content: For this movie to be classified as bad. I had never seen this movie until a week ago, and I am not planning on watching it again. The acting was not good and the songs were not original as well as  underachieving. I am a fan of Michele Pfeiffer and I was looking forward to seeing her in this early role. Altho I was delighted at her moves in the song "Cool Rider", that was the extent of it. As for this being her "best" role as I have seen others claim, you might want to watch "I Am Sam" or "What Lies Beneath" to truly appreciate her abilities. I did not attempt to compare this film with the original movie, but there seemed to be little heart put into it, just a hope for a quick buck off the original. That didn't happen, tho.

I once had a dream that Grease had a sequel.  Turns out this dream is not only true, but that it is actually a nightmare.  Someone said that the songs from this movie are not cheesy.  That person is right because IMHO these songs suck.  "Reproduction", "Score Tonight", "Let's Do It For Our Country", and a whole mess of other babblings that some considered "songs". Michelle Pfeiffer cannot sing, but atleast she is better than Maxwell Caulfield.  I can understand why this movie is in "bottom 100".

This movie is really not that bad. I enjoyed it much more than the original, since it encouraged individuality, while the first one not only failed at that, but also totally messed with a good musical in order to make it more of a showcase of the talents of John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John.

Disjointed, fractured scenes. Lame script.
Inept acting. Completely forgettable in whole and part.

Yes, it's true. Grease 2 is a bad, bad, awful movie. I LOVE IT!The script is terrible. Many of the songs are pretty awful. But overall, I think the actors did a good job of making the best of what they had to work with.In reading these posts I see that people are either trashing or praising the songs in this movie, but no one has mentioned the best song of the whole film: "Prowlin'" sung by Adrian Zmed and the T-Birds. Seriously! This song is so much fun! Try playing it loudly and singing along sometime. It's great.I think that the Grease 2 soundtrack is quite special because it features one of the best movie songs ever (Prowlin') followed by the all-time worst (Reproduction). Both songs are kind of funny, but "Reproduction" is only funny because it's so bad. "Prowlin" is funny because it perfectly captures the ridiculous characterizations that were written for those T-Birds. And those four actors made it work, I tell you!

reviews.review_title: I think that this movie was the best!
reviews.content: I liked Grease 2 better then Grease because I think that it was a lot funnier.  I also liked Maxwell Caulfield because I think that he is totally cute.  The minute I saw him in the movie, I knew that he would be my favorite actor in the whole world!  Anyway, I really liked this movie and I'll watch it over and over again for the rest of my life!

This movie would be an okay movie if it didn't have those terrible songs. It seems like they thought they could turn any subject that was happening in the movie could be turned into a song.  For example, they had song while they were bowling(wtf) and when they were learning sex ed.  The songs in 'Grease' actually had something to do with the plot.  The songs were so bad, that if they had the same writers for the first one, they probably would have made everyone dance at the pep rally or something.  Just terrible!  I never thought of this until I saw the tv show 'stripperella' make fun of it. If you can tolerate the movie with all the bad songs then go ahead and see it.  I give it a 1.5 out of 4.  It's only worth it if it's on tv.

Absolutely dire, both performance and story wise. Characters were one dimensional and I couldn't relate to any of them. Worse of all was the wooden acting by the vast majority of the cast and not a single memorable song. Appalling attempt at entertainment. I'd be surprised if any of them got any work after this effort.

reviews.review_title: If only I didn't see the first Grease
reviews.content: This movie was on Netflix so I decided to watch it. I hadn't seen Grease in years so that was the last thing on my mind while watching it. I enjoyed it. It wasn't necessarily bad just boring. The things I did like about it was the song Cool Rider and the character of Michael was generally likable. One complaint I do have is during one of his songs it is so obvious he doesn't sing it. If I didn't watch Grease right after this what have gotten 6 stars. However I did. I was laughing all through the movie and singing along and that is a movie that holds up over years. Grease 2 just didn't capture the spirit of the first Grease. Grease 2 was raunchy and not in a good way. In Grease the dirty jokes were clever and they were just kind of there in Grease 2. The characters in Grease 2 weren't memorable either. All in all, don't bother with Grease 2 if you can watch Grease.

reviews.review_title: one of the worst movies in history
reviews.content:
This movie was terrible.  Grease is one of my top 3 favorite movies ever and i was very disappointed when i saw this.  It was beyond bad.  I did like a few of the songs like "Reproduction" but besides that it was just plain terrible.  Don't waste your time.
2/10

To be honest I believe this movie was never going to be considered that good because it lives in the shadow of the first one. I think this movie tried too hard to be like the original, following the same basic story line but this time the guy changing for the girl.also I don't think the actors portrayed the 'T-birds' and 'Pink ladies' very well.The new characters were clones of the original ones, similar personalities, hairstyles and even similar names. The songs were the worst part, they were bland and boring they didn't pump me up like 'grease lighting' or 'summer nights' would. I gave the movie a chance and while others may like it I wouldn't give it the time of day.

One bad movie I didn't see the movie when it first came out and glad I didn't spend my 2.50 back then 😂😂😂 and would of been more upset had I to pay 3.99 now How can anybody think this is good First we have California kids talking and like stereotypical Italian New York teens sure it was somewhat over looked in the first one but it can't be in this heap of trash I can't give a real review as I couldn't get pass the first ten minutes.

reviews.review_title: Cousin to the first Grease...very distant cousin
reviews.content: Let's be honest.  This is so bad, it's good.  The lens used on Lorna Luft is so fuzzy, it doesn't make her look younger, it makes her look out of focus. The songs are so sappy, you have to love them.  "Charade," when you can see the previous heart outlines on the notebook as Max draws..."Score," with the choppy edit...these are just a couple of things that endear you to this movie.  You get the feeling that you and your buddies could have done better.  That's alone is worth the price of the rental.  Pardon me, now, it's time to "Do It For Our Country."

You really can't expect a sequel to own up to the glory that is "Grease." The expectations were to high and the hopes were too high. Give it a chance, gosh.That said I really can't say this was a very good film, but I enjoyed it. The story was a great idea, I think it just suffered from faulty script and a miscast when it came to the T-Birds and the Pink Ladies.A simple formula: Boy wants girl, girl won't give boy the time of day, boy works hard and even changes his image for this girl and eventually gets her as she realizes she wanted him along.Overall, I say the movie was cute. It was the cute little movie that couldn't, but hey, look what happened to Michelle Pfeiffer! SO be happy for that. I say-5 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Gee...I hope they restore this film too.
reviews.content: I'm sorry, but even TJ Hooker's Adrian Zmed couldn't save this sequel.  I went through half the movie thinking that this was a spoof of the original. Then came that wild and wacky motorcycle scene (notice that this is the only movie that Patricia Birch directs); and I sadly realized they were trying to be serious.  I did get a kick out of the fact that the opposing gang, having lost their "wheels" due to their gambling habits in the original Grease, were forced to use motorcycles in the second movie.  Being shamed by that putz character Carrington, I'd hate to see what they would resort to later: maybe Mopeds?I also never bought the hackneyed theme: hunky-Australian-boy-can't-fit-into-Outsiders-dominated-school-ergo-goes-for -tough-guy-with-stupid-biker-helmet-look. It was Disney story gone horribly awry.So, it looks like you CAN ruin a good thing by placing a bubble-gum smacking Michelle Pfeiffer in a musical.  The only thing I took away from this movie was an idea of how many points out of ten to give it.

reviews.review_title: Great movie...if you have low expectations
reviews.content: This movie is definitely a lame, unoriginal sequel to a classic movie (although the original play is even better) but with all that in mind it can be an enjoyable movie.  Everything about this movie is cheezy, especially the songs, so if you're ever in the mood for a good laugh at a bad movie, rent this.

Although the actors are better looking the movie wasn't all that good. The actors didn't have great voices either. The characters were awful. The actors are good actors and the movie was just a black spot on their careers. The plot was weak, it didn't really have a middle to the story. It didn't seem as if the writers of the movie knew what they were doing. It wasn't all that exciting. They could have made it a lot better. I only liked about one or two of the songs. I'm not saying it is the worst movie in the world because I have seen worse, it just could have been made a little better than it was. The first Grease was a whole lot better. You can't top it and they shouldn't have tried.

reviews.review_title: Not too bad, but grease was better
reviews.content: Frankly I like the music and the acting isn't bad. I really am a big fan of Michelle Pheifer, so anything she is in she shines. Max Claudfield is cute but seems not so real. Didi Conn was great in the first movie and this one she was still a cutie, but not the same caliber as before. All of the other characters are well played. The movie's story is not so good but still is entertaining. The songs leave a sexual impression in most scenes but they are still fun hearted. I like this movie for the actors and the music. I do not like the story because it has nothing really to do with Grease one except for brief nuances of certain characters (i.e. Sandie, Her parents and Vince Fontaine).

I will just start this by saying that Grease 2 is one of my all time favorite movies ever made. Yes, it is cheesy, yes, most of it is a stretch of the imagination, but it's got heart, and personally, I find it a hundred times more romantic and fun then the original. I appreciate the original, because without it, the second one would never have gotten made, but other than that, I think the original is pretty bland and not 1/2 as funny or charming as the second. Grease 2 has such a fantastic cast, and although I have seen comments that the songs are ridiculous as well as the movie itself, I really can't understand where people are coming from on this. The songs are terrific and humorous as well as being extremely catchy! My heart melts a little every time I watch this movie, which is often. It has kept my interest and my loyalty for decades, and I feel a little bit sorry for people out there who don't have the same fondness for it. They are really missing out.

Not to be compared with the original - shrug off the 1978 classic and watch this film in the same light as you would one of those 60's beach party movies (come on,you know you enjoy them!)Reversing the formula of the original by featuring a bad girl/good boy love affair just doesn't work. Let's face it ,bad girl/bad boy love affairs are the only ones that do. But the dialogue and songs are hilarious,check out 'lets do it for our country'.Try it,cast aside the shackles of ingrained film snobbery and enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Sing along with Max and the gang!!!
reviews.content: OK so it's not as good as the original with John Travlota and Olivia Newton-John but it's pretty fun anyway.  Maxwell Caulfield is good (and sexy!) and Michelle Whats-her-name is also good.  I like this movie!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Grease 2 shouldn't have been dismissed; it's the best film ever.
reviews.content: I found this an excellent film, i thought it contained great actors, great music and a wicked storyline. Although the first one is just a classic and John Travolta could not have been any better than he was i agree with people when they say that it was boring at times (watching it once is OK but when you love it that much and watch it over and over again then it will get a bit boring) so when i watch it now i skip a lot of parts. Anyway, we're talking about Grease 2 now!I give Grease (9/10) but i give Greae 2 (10/10), i'd give it more if i could. Every actor deserved their part and it was nice to see Blanche and Miss McGee (the dynamic duo) again in this film, Frenchy's appearance showed it as a follow on from Grease but it shouldn't be told as a sequel (although it's the best sequel ever), they should be treated as two separate films as they have different story lines and only a few of the same characters (i think it may not have been AS good without these characters). Grease 2 is a treat and i love it, although one main reason may be because the leading lady has my name but i also love the actors, the humour, the music and just the plain simplicity of it. Maxwell Caulfield (Michael), Adrian Zmed (Johnny) are gorgeous, Peter Frechette (Louis) is soooooo cute and Christopher McDonald (Goose) and Leif Green (Davey) are just plain hilarious. All the pink ladies make great pink ladies and the ending couldn't be more perfect; everyone has someone and it's so romantic. THIS FILM SHOULD HAVE BEEN AWARDED!!!I even love Leo 'Craterface' Balmudo in this one, although he is the villain he is funny. (Although i don't get why he's the leader of the Scorpions in Grease and Cycle Lords in Grease 2!?)

i absolutely love this film, and hate to hear it bad mouthed, which is very common. i cannot fault the film, i've been its number one film for as long as i can remember. the songs are fantastic and i love the actors. i was originally a "grease" megafan, but once i'd seen grease 2, there was no competition. i think i love it so much because it is obviously nowhere near as commericialised as "grease" is. michelle pfeiffer and maxwell caulfield show they're up for a laugh, and the supporting cast are pure comedy. i love christopher mcdonald and adrian zmed in particular, and have followed their careers following "grease 2". here comes the cheese=it will always be a "cool rider" with me!! :D

A brilliant film, and in my opinion better than the first one, but that is up to the individual viewer to decide. Excellent actors especially Maxwell Caulfield, what a great guy. A roller coaster of fun and excitement from start to finish. The way that the 80's actors portrayed the 60's genre is incredible. The sort of film to be watched over and over again. I particularly loved the way that the comedy and romance were combined together. I would recommend this film to anyone, and because of the way it has been made, it would appeal to male or female viewers of any age, in my household I love the film to bits as does my Daughter 16 and Son 7, it is a definite 10 out of 10 for us.

reviews.review_title: Nice story spoilt by bad production values.
reviews.content: If you look past the terrible production values of this movie, what you actually find is a fairly decent and engaging little story about a guy trying to woo a girl who seems unattainable, and I have to say that contrary to popular belief, Maxwell Caulfield and Michelle Pfeiffer both give very good performances.There are some aspects to this film that are a little odd, in that we are led to believe that Michael is a nerd in the movie, yet is bigger, better built and more handsome than any one of the T-Birds. Indeed, it is they who appear to be the 'nerds' as unlike the 1st movie, the T-Birds in Grease 2 really have no credibility and are scared whenever Balmudo's gang show up.Plus, there is some very cynical re-casting of some of the old faces from Grease, such as the Mr. Spears character and Coach Calhoun, etc, but they really have no role in the movie and you feel they are only there to lend some weight and collect a pay check.However, that said, Maxwell Caulfield really is excellent in the role of Michael, making his character believable and sympathetic, although despite the fact that he is the leading actor of the movie, he has curiously few scenes and it leads one to suspect that quite a few of his scenes hit the cutting room floor.I really found his scenes with Michelle Pfeiffer endearing, particularly at the burger-joint and during his 'Charades' song. What a talent he was and should really have gone on to become a major film star. What a waste, but at least we have his sincere performance in this movie to enjoy.

I think Grease 2 is better then Grease. The only problem is, they should not have named it Grease 2, they could have named it something else. It didn't have any of the same actors/actresses & the story was different other then the school. The music in Grease 2 is much more superior then the first one. However, I do like these songs from Grease: Summer Nights, Sandy & We Go Together. Anybody that says Grease 2 movie & music was & is no good, knows nothing about music or movies. I am really surprised that Maxwell Caulfield didn't succeed in movies. He is an excellent Actor & very good looking. It is unfortunate that mainly Michelle Pfeiffer was the only one from Grease 2 to really succeed.

A fantastic sequel to one of the best movies of all time. With a fantastic cast and a great plot "Grease 2" brings enjoyment for everyone. Packed with brilliant music and great characters, this movie truly is one of the best. Many familiar faces from "Grease" return for "Grease 2" putting the cherry on top of the cake. Its a shame that "Grease 2" wasn't as big as a hit as "Grease" because it really does deserve it! This movie really did put Michelle Pfeiffer on the map, with an outstanding performance. Maxwell Caulfield also gave a fantastic performance, and of course, the rest of the cast did too. "Grease 2" really is a brilliant movie.

This movie was fantastic! I loved every minute of it. This movie's one of those films I could watch every week and not get sick of it. Although I am rather getting sick of the songs in my head for the past day and a half after watching it only once. The songs in the movie were so catchy, so amazingly good that how CAN I stop thinking about them? Michelle Pfeiffer was awesome as the lead role, I haven't seen better acting by any woman in anything. Definitely my favorite movie she's been in and most definitely this movie is in my top ten. And Maxwell Caulfield.., what a cutie! I fell in love with his character and his attempts at winning Stephanie's (Pfeiffer) heart.This movie is a must see. To me, this movie was better than the original. Much better. Don't get me wrong. I enjoyed the first one but the second one blows it out of the water. Please see the movie because I think you'll love it as much as I do.

this is a sad attempt to capitalize on the original's success. almost EVERY scene with Michelle Pfeiffer is not era appropriate clothing or hair n make-up for the times. You could 'plunk' her, (and her character) out of this movie and insert her into St Elmo's Fire or The Breakfast Club and have everything current with the fashion of the time. did she insist on only doing this movie if she could appear in a manner as she wouldn't be embarrassed? i was Born in the 60's and she does NOT represent the 60's by a LONG shot. i did not ONCE see era appropriate hair one her.. where was the structure curl of 'roller setting' on her? and the Sad portrayal of every one of the main characters as IDIOTS. the making of this movie should NEVER have been associated with the first Grease and should have been made as more of a parody for the times, but not be linked with the first Grease. the characters of the first were NOT so shallow and stupid as these people were who were supposed to be following in the footsteps of COOL people.

While Grease 2 may not one of the greatest movies around, and I would never pay to rent it, I will admit when it is on TV I will watch it.  The main problem with the film is that in a musical the lead actress can not sing. And for those of you who are either praising or condemning Michelle Pfeiffers singing, you can't do either because she is lip singing, not one of those musical sounds are actually coming from her.
One of the worst movies I've ever watched from beginning to end.  The plot and the acting (especially the acting) is so lame, it's actually fun to watch!

If you watched the original "Grease" then this will most likely be a disappointment. I liked the idea - the tough chick falling for the sweet guy, but I think it could have been produced much better. The music wasn't all that great, neither with the dance sequences. I knew before I turned it on that it would not be able to the exact standards "Grease" did but I didn't expect to be this much of a disappointment. Stick to watching the classic. Though, I'll admit, the movie wasn't totally bogus. I really enjoyed Micheal's character and I liked seeing Frenchy again - she was my favourite character from the original. I thought it was weird that the 'Pink Ladies' were now owned by the T-Birds; they couldn't date outside the group because they were the T-Birds girls. That just didn't match up to me. The 'Reproduction' scene was kind of cool, I suppose.

reviews.review_title: You'll love it or you'll hate it.
reviews.content: Grease 2 is actually a phenomenon that has gone totally unrecognized by the mainstream media. It has a significant cult following, evidenced by the incredible amount of enthusiastic support I have received for my website.For many of us, Grease 2 appeals on a really schlocky level. If you open your mind to the silliness of it all, you will love this movie and watch it again and again. Spread the word...Jack Humphrey (President and Co-Founder, Son of Grease Fan Club)

I thought Grease 2 was going to be another huge hit, like the original But sadly, I was disappointed by how the film went.There were a new group of T-Birds and Pink Ladies in Rydell High. Michelle Pfeiffer played as Stephanie Zinone, leader of the Pink Ladies, who thinks that she no longer has interest in Johnny Nogerelli (Adrian Zmed). Then there comes Michael Carrington (Maxwell Caulfield), the cousin of Sandy, who fancies Stephanie in some way. He'll try to make her notice him by being "cool" even if he's got the brains in the class.I was surprised by Frenchy (played by Didi Conn) She was rarely seen on the movie. She did very well in the first Grease movie. She deserves more lines than that.The songs were not as great as the ones from the original. Tough there are some parts of it were not really that bad.It didn't really beat Grease 1 but it's not that much bad. They should work more on the plot.All in all, I give it: 6/10

The movie was okay but it's downfall was that though it was named Grease 2 it had no significant relevance to the original, apart from the song theme and the greasers.If the director had used a different name then may be the reaction of the viewers might have been different.

Grease 2 succeeds with it's full throttle BACK TO SCHOOL AGAIN opening number and other catchy tunes. The only noticeable flaw was the lack of period music that filled up the first films soundtrack. There are times when it doesn't have the feel of the early 60's and that could have been fixed with more backround music typical of the era. I think most people missed the way too subtle comedy touches such as the T-BIRDS smoking and chewing bubble gum at the same time. They are trying to look older and very cool, yet they are not willing to give up the bubblegum of their youth. Clever! The staging of its musical numbers is great in that it utilizes unusual settings such as a bowling alley, bomb shelter and a boys v.s. girls sex education classroom song. Maxwell Caulfield sings beautifully and and more than pulls his share of the weight of this picture, Adrian Zmed is less lucky and almost sinks the whiny but bouncy "SCORE TONIGHT" number.But then we come back to the very subtle comic antics of having included NUNS in the bowling alley production, singing and dancing with the rest of the gang! Inspired! Will any one forget the image of Michelle Pfeiffer straddling the ladder during "COOL RIDER"? Then to show her independence, turning her reversable pink ladies jacket inside out to show a shiny black jacket?Great images! The ending could have had a few more twists and turns ,but over all GREASE 2 is a lot of fun and in many mays surpasses the original in its creativity and boundless energy.

reviews.review_title: I've seen this movie since I was ten and it never gets old. It's still good, clean fun, with decent music that bops along. It's not as good as "Grease 1" as a whole, but in a lot of ways, the two a
reviews.content: I've seen this movie since I was ten, stuck in the house all summer long watching PG-rated movies and nothing else. Since then, I have seen it 43 times! It never gets old. I even have my own website though it's not up and running yet. I am also hoping to plan a 20th anniversary showing of the movie. OK, it's no "Citizen Kane" or "Stalag 17" (my two favorite movies of all time---they each get **** out of 4, or a 10 out of a 10), but it's still good, clean fun, with decent music that really bops along. It's not as good as "Grease 1" as a whole, but in a lot of ways, the two are similar. If anyone wishes to see a really bad musical from that same time era (the late '70s and early '80s), perhaps a trip to the video store for a rental of "Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band" or "Xanadu" might help. (I will admit those two films had good soundtracks in spite of themselves.) Even if you don't like "Grease 2," you'll definitely agree it's better than those two turkeys.

This sequel is better than its original, mainly because its T-Birds are less violent and more playful than what John Travolta was in "Grease"(notice how the first movie's Danny Zucko smacked or almost smacked anyone who slighted him when Zucko tried out for sports ?). Adrian (T.J. Hooker) Zmed's Johnny Nogerelli is more subdued as are the new T-Birds and, towards the end, Zmed's Nogerelli WELCOMES Caufield's Michael Carrington as new T-Bird complete with a black T-Bird jacket.

This movie is not the original "Grease", so just get over it and enjoy it for what it actually is; a rollicking, colorful, sometimes cheesy yet very fun movie.  The songs are catchy and very entertaining, while the characters are amusing.  I was a non-believer until my girlfriend, who absolutely loves it, made me watch and I had a great time!  So lighten up and have some fun!

I liked watching this movie in my early teens and now my preteen children have just seen it for the first time (bought the DVD) and they thought it was great. The problem with this movie has always been the connection to Grease. The movie by itself is entertaining, it should have been given a different name though. This is probably one of those movies that many people like but are embarrassed to admit it!It is not to say Grease 2 doesn't get corny at times. A few of the songs are really lame. Most of the music while not epic is fun and memorable. There is more humor than the original and the theme of guys trying to get sex from girls keeps the movie flowing together. Who could forget the "Let's do it for our country" scene!

reviews.review_title: This is the most fantastic film i have ever seen

I was 14 years old when I saw this movie. I loved it. I really thought it was charming and liked the fact that it was a reversal role of the first movie. I felt that they did a great job with the costumes. The costumes were not 80's at all, the problem is that in the 80's anything that was worn in the 50's and 60's just happen to be in again. So of course to some people it seemed like instead of wearing 60's clothes they were wearing 80's.True Michelle's singing was not that great, but i think she gets a b for effort. The acting was pretty good considering most of the stars had never been seen acting before. I certainly don't feel this movie was a disaster. True it would never be an academy award winner, but it was still charming and many of those that say they don't like , its only because there too embarrassed to admit they liked it.

i'm sure that there are absolutely loads of people who would not touch this film in a million years-well in fact i know this from EX-girlfriends whom i could not convince to watch it(on many occasion it has been the last straw!), but if you start watching this film just accepting that it's going to be a bit naff then i think you can really enjoy it."Grease" is one of my all-time favourite films and to be honest I enjoy "Grease 2" just as much, in fact were they both of the tele at the same time i would probably watch the later and flick to the previous from time to time. Grease 2 is the ultimate Sunday lunchtime hangover film, with not too much going on, just some light-hearted singing and dancing with a few scuffles to keep your ears open if not your eyes.I think that Michelle Phiffier is excellent and plays the role in exactly the right spirit, with the diner scene being one of the bests. It does not try to be the first film the only real connection is Rydall High.Take no high ideals into this film, just take it as the light-hearted bit of silliness it is and enjoy it.
